Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_4.text: This is the part-2 of a series of posts explaining multi-threading using coroutines. If you didnâ€™t check the first part, here is the link. I recommend you to read it before you continue reading this part, it present some of fundamental concept of coroutines. In this part, we will talk about async, withContext and exception handling.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_6.text: So what is an async in coroutines and why they are so useful ? Remember the launch that we talked about in the last part ? In fact async is just like launch it starts a coroutine except that it return a result. The only difference between async and a normal function is that async start a coroutine that run in a different thread with parallel with the main thread so the result returned by async is deferred in time until the coroutine finish the work and return the result. Thatâ€™s why the async return what we call a Deferred. So once we need the result of that coroutine, we call the method await() to get the value. In fact this method is a blocking method, thatâ€™s mean if the value is ready it will return it immediately otherwise it will block the thread until it become available and at that time it returns the value.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_7.text: Letâ€™s see in practice how we use an async . So we will write a small program that has two suspend functions returning each an Integer after some work (for simplicity of the example we will just add a delay), than we will print the sum of these two numbers! easy isnâ€™t it ? :D

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_8.name: f3e6

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_9.name: 8e58
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_9.text: So here we have these two function that will do some work than each return an Integer. In the main program, we launch these two function in an async in order to get the result. After launching these two asyncs, letâ€™s say we have a small processing of 500 millis in our program and then, we want to get the values from the two functions in order to print there sum! In order to get the value immediately, we must call the method await to force the async to get the value! Actually, it will pause the current thread, execute the work until the value is ready and then return it. Try to run this code and see the output and the delays between each print.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_10.name: c9e2
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_10.text:
main Doing some processing!
Waiting for values
main returning first value: 72
main returning second value: 76
the sum is 148

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_11.text: So thatâ€™s it for the async !

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_12.text: Remember, use launch when you donâ€™t have a value to return from that coroutine, use async in case you expect a value !

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_14.name: 8d82
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_14.text: Itâ€™s no more than a function! withContext is a function that allows us to switch between Dispatchers inside a coroutine.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_15.name: 3dce
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_15.text: Letâ€™s say we have an Android application that will apply a filter on an Image before showing it. Of course applying a filter is an intensif work we canâ€™t apply it in the UiThread. So we must launch a coroutine with Dispatchers.Default (Use Default Dispatchers for CPU processing works) and then once the image is ready, we show it in the UI. Now to show the image in the UI thread, we must switch from the background thread that applied the filter on the image to the UI thread that will show the filtered image. In order to do that, we just call the function withContext(Dispatchers.Main(){//Show the image} and that code will be executed in the main dispatcher given to the method withContext() which is the UiThread in Android.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_16.text: Letâ€™s go through an example, we will just print the coroutineContext in each scope and see whatâ€™s the dispatcher the code is running on.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_17.name: e720

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_18.name: 20a2
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_18.text: When we run this code we get this output:

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_22.name: b5e5
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_22.text: For the first and the third message, itâ€™s the same context, the same Dispatcher (in my case itâ€™s @d018aa4) but for the second message which is printed inside a withContext method, the context here is changed (and the dispatcher obviously).

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_23.name: 507d
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_23.text: The withContext is very useful method especially when working on Android application and you need to update the UI in the main thread.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_25.text: In this section we will talk about exception handling in coroutine. In fact it depends weither we started the coroutine by launch or async method. The launch method return a Job , the async return a Deferred .

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_28.name: 1c93
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_28.text: The exception will be thrown immediately and jobs will fail.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_29.name: 2cb8
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_29.text: Use try/catch or an exception handling.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_31.text: Exceptions are deferred until the value is consumed (by calling the await() function).

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_32.name: e7be
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_32.text: If the result is not consumed, the exception is never thrown.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_33.name: 5afc
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_33.text: Use try-catch in the coroutine or in the await call.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_34.name: fffa
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_34.text: Now letâ€™s try to handle exceptions in both cases.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_35.name: 867a
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_35.text: we will start by launch , the example is quiet simple, we are going to launch a coroutine and throw an Exception, then we will join this job to the main context (If we donâ€™t join the job, we will not get the exception).

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_36.name: 1e30

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_37.name: 3aa9
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_37.text: Once we run this code we will get a beautiful IllegalStateException!

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_38.name: baf7
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_38.text: So the question is how we are going to handle this exception?

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_39.name: 6ed4
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_39.text: Coroutines offers an exception handler that we can create and pass it as parameter to the launch method.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_40.name: 1c6b
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_40.text: First, letâ€™s create the exception handler:

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_42.name: 8b7d
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_42.text: thatâ€™s it! now we can add this handler to our job so we can handle the exception.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_44.text: now try to run this code and you will see that the exception is handled and the program doesnâ€™t crash any more.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_45.text: Now, what if we want launch the coroutine in a different dispatcher and with an exception handler that we defined ?

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_46.name: eaca
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_46.text: itâ€™s quiet easy, we have just to add it as parameter in the launch method this way:

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_48.name: 8ed0
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_48.text: So now we have a coroutine launched in IO Dispatcher with an exception handler that we defined.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_49.text: Now letâ€™s talk about async function. letâ€™s launch an async and call the await method and see how we can catch the exception.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_50.name: 3a27

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_51.name: 5bf5
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_51.text: Now if you run this code you will get an IllegalStateException. To catch the exception, we can use the classic try-catch bloc. We have two options, we can catch the exception once we call the await function or inside the async function itself. the code will be:

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_52.name: b05f

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_53.text: And now the exception is caught!

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_55.name: b7c8
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_55.text: To summarize all the knowledge we gained, letâ€™s implement a small Android application. This application will be very simple, we are going to download an image, apply a filter, and then show it in the UI. Itâ€™s a small application but itâ€™s enough to use all concepts that we talked about in these two posts.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_56.name: 2df3
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_56.text: I assume that you have a knowledge about Android development so I am not going just to explain the coroutines bloc of code.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_57.text: To start, add the coroutines-core dependencies in your app/build.gradle file

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_59.name: ede2
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_59.text: After adding the dependencies, go to your activity_main file and place this code:

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_60.name: 78fb
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_60.text:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="match_parent"
    tools:context=".MainActivity">

    <ImageView
        android:id="@+id/imageView"
        android:layout_width="300dp"
        android:layout_height="300dp"
        android:scaleType="centerCrop"
        android:visibility="gone"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintEnd_toEndOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent"
        app:srcCompat="@mipmap/ic_launcher" />

    <ProgressBar
        android:id="@+id/progressBar"
        style="?android:attr/progressBarStyle"
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintEnd_toEndOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" />
</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_61.name: 9bd6
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_61.text: The UI will be as simple as possible. We just have an ImageView to show the filtered image and a ProgressBar to show while waiting fetching and processing the image.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_62.text: Now in your MainActivity we are going to download the image, apply a filter and show the filtered image. All this stuff will be done by coroutines!

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_63.name: 2e03
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_63.text: I will first put the code than we will discuss it.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_64.name: 2f73

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_65.name: 927d
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_65.text: Letâ€™s start with the two function in the bottom of the class. the getOriginalImage will download an image from an url and return a Bitmap. the loadImage will hide the progressBar, make the ImageView visible and show the bitmap.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_66.name: 3af1
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_66.text: Now as you can see in the top of the class we declared a coroutineScope that will be running in Main Dispatcher which is UiTread in Android.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_67.name: e96c
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_67.text: We launch this coroutine with launch function (we are not waiting a return value from this coroutine). Inside this coroutine, we create a Deferred that will download the image. Now, downloading an image is a read/write operation. For that kind of work, we do it in the Dispatchers.IO and thatâ€™s why in the async function we switched the dispatcher to the IO dispatcher so all the bloc inside the async(Dispatcher.IO){//block} will be executed in an IO dispatcher.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_68.name: 80a7
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_68.text: So now we need the downloaded image to apply the filter, but itâ€™s running in different thread so we must wait for it until itâ€™s downloaded. here comes the utility of await function, it will suspend the current thread until we get the value needed. So when here:

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_70.name: 17a4
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_70.text: The main thread will be suspended until the deferred that will return the downloaded image return this image.

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_71.name: 7c56
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_71.text: After we get the image, we now can apply the filter. Applying a filter is an intensive CPU work. For that kind of work, we must choose the Default dispatcher! Thatâ€™s why in our code we declared a deferred(because we are waiting a result from the coroutine) that will be run in Dispatchers.Default

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_73.name: 37b5
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_73.text: calling await on this deferred will also suspend the current thread until we get the result, in our case the filtered image and now we can set the ImageView with the filtered image! Remember that we are in a coroutine thatâ€™s running on the Main dispatcher, so we donâ€™t need to switch the context!

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_74.name: 22df
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_74.text: In android, there is another Dispatcher in ViewModels to do your work. All you need to do is viewModelScope.launch{//your beautiful code}

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_76.name: afd4
Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_76.text: By reading these two parts of coroutines-basics and implementing this sample, you are now must be able to develop a whole application using Coroutines :D

Paragraph:aee55f41d64d_77.text: For some Frameworks that support coroutines like Room or Retrofit they return suspend functions, use these function in the main thread is safe so you donâ€™t need to define a Dispatcher before calling these functions because they are main-safe.

Post:4087ce15ff28.title: Kotlin Coroutines Basics part-2
Post:4087ce15ff28.seoDescription: This post explain the async and withContext functions in coroutines. And it presents the different ways to handle exceptions for coroutines
